AMZN's ~50% ($965mn) better than expected 2Q gaap operating profit and guidance increase (top end of 3Q operating profit 29% higher than our previous estimate) re-enforces our bullish view that AMZN's growing high margin revenue streams (advertising/AWS/subscription) are increasingly allowing AMZN to post record profitability even through continued reinvestment in the business. Other revenue, which is predominantly comprised of advertising, grew 64% y/y excluding the impacts of accounting changes, as the company talked to having hundreds of thousands of advertisers and a growing global presence. More encouragingly, despite likely 60%+ growth, Amazon also spoke to all the advertising areas it aims to improve including: usability of tools for advertisers, making smarter recommendations, automating advertiser workflows, measurement, and continuing to invest in new ad products. AMZN's high margin advertising business is only getting started. As shown in Exhibit 3, we expect the operating profit from these high margin businesses to reach $25bn in 2018...and $43.5bn in 2020.

With the shares arguably pricing in a profit warning (down 36% since their March high) it is very reassuring to see a 7.7% 1H organic print with overall revenue and EBITA ahead of expectations (+c3%). Three key highlights: 1) UK trading is strong. Both Investment Solutions (+6.7% organic) and Intelligent Solutions (up c35%) are performing well. Pensions is no worse than guided, with margins flat;

BE11:27am

2) The quality of earnings is improving. There was a small working capital cash inflow in 1H and the factoring facility has shrunk by 30% since the year end. An expected, £2m pensions restructuring charge is now being absorbed above the line, mitigated by higher underlying profits elsewhere. WFSS’s exceptional integration costs are running in-line with guidance and forecasts;

3) US integration is on track: “proceeding well” and within budget. In terms of outlook, management see EBITDA towards the upper end of company compiled market expectations (EBITDA of £116.0m-122.9m). We raise our FY18 revenue forecasts by 2%; assuming organic of 3.8%; EBITDA by c2%; EBITA & EPS are unchanged, held back by higher D&A. Given the de-rating the shares now trade on c10x FY19e PE. For a business delivering mid single digit organic, the shares are mispriced in our view. Reiterate Overweight with c60% implied upside to our 335p price target.

After a pronounced selloff in response to mgmt comments about forward growth & margin trajectory, we now see the risk/reward as balanced for FB going forward – strong momentum in Instagram measured against regulatory attention, investments to transform/protect ecosystem, & slowing engagement/more mature ad trends at core FB (based on our work – link). In our opinion, the new growth drivers (Instagram, Watch, Stories, Messenger/WhatsApp, VR) frankly aren’t big enough over the short/medium term to alter the decelerating growth & margin pressure profile of the P&L ( link). We have seen the playbook of decelerating growth and margin pressure – normally a valuation argument built on the forward P/E multiple doesn’t win out the day (perfect example was GOOG from '10-‘13) esp. against a high absolute market cap. Where could we be wrong? – a valuation framework emerges if Street ests de-risk enough, ad growth surprises to upside and/or fears of opex/capex pressure prove to be unfounded.

M&G Prudential today announces changes to its senior leadership team in preparation for its planned demerger from Prudential plc (the Group).

M&G Prudential was formed in 2017 through the combination of M&G Investments and Prudential's UK & Europe life business. The changes announced today reflect the growing integration of these business units over the past year and will prepare M&G Prudential to operate as an independent business.

Anne Richards, currently Chief Executive of M&G Investments, is resigning from this role and from the Board of Prudential plc effective on 10 August 2018, following the delivery of the Group's 2018 half year results, in order to take up a new senior leadership position in the financial services industry.

Pearson’s 1H results are never going to provide a definitive take on
the outcome for the FY but the clear message from today’s update is that the business is on track. Underlying revenues and operating profitability are up YoY and comfortably ahead of expectations. FY guidance has been reiterated (indeed, given it now includes the impact of the WSE sale it has actually been slightly increased) and even currency is now a tailwind suggesting mild upward pressure to consensus. This is not to say the group doesn’t have challenges, but with guidance conservatively set and the balance sheet entirely derisked (we expect ‘core’ net cash and the pension in surplus) it strikes us as odd that the market is so cautious on Pearson (sell side: 11 sells vs 2 buys. Buyside: 12% short interest at 2 year high). We are Buyers and think the group will continue to outperform as they build up a track record for delivering.
